headline.main: THE OUTLOOK: The Future; Plan Is No Panacea But a Remedy for Costs And Major Inequities

docs.lead_paragraph: Suppose President Clinton's health plan is adopted. Suppose every American gets a health insurance card and no one need worry again about being uninsured. Will the nation be healthier? The answer might seem obvious. After all, 37 million Americans are uninsured. How could the plan do anything but improve the overall health of the country?

docs.lead_paragraph: Andreas Gembler, the head of the Philip Morris International tobacco operations in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, points to a simple statistic to explain the company's decision to sink nearly $1 billion into the region after the collapse of Communism. About 700 billion cigarettes are sold there annually, making the market 40 percent larger than that of the United States. "No industry can ignore the consumer in this part of the world," Mr. Gembler said.
